hints.content:
The derivatives are

$\qquad \dfrac{d}{dx}(\tan x)=\sec^2 x$


and $\qquad \dfrac{d}{dx}(\tan^{-1} x)=\dfrac{1}{1+x^2}\,$.

At $\displaystyle ~x=0\,$,

$\qquad \dfrac{d}{dx}(\tan x)\Big|_{x=0}=\sec^2 (0)=1$

and $\qquad \dfrac{d}{dx}\tan^{-1} x \Big|_{x=0}=\dfrac{1}{1+0^2}=1\,$.

The first statement is **TRUE**.

The slopes along both $~f~$ and $~g~$ are postively valued. Since the product of two positive numbers in positive, we have $\displaystyle ~f\,^\prime(x)\cdot g\,^\prime (x)>0\,$.

The second statement is **TRUE**.

The derivatives are

$\qquad f\,^\prime (x)=\sec^2 x$


and $\qquad g\,^\prime (x)=\dfrac{1}{1+x^2}\,$.

At $\displaystyle ~x=\pi /4~$ and $~x=1\,$, respectively, we have

$\qquad f\,^\prime (\pi /4)=\sec^2 (\pi /4)=\sqrt{2}^2=2$

and $\qquad g\,^\prime (1)=\dfrac{1}{1+1^2}=\dfrac{1}{2}\,$.

It follows that

$\qquad \displaystyle f\,^\prime(\pi /4)\cdot g\,^\prime (1)=2\cdot\dfrac{1}{2}=1\,$.

The third statement is **TRUE**.

question.content:
The graphs of $\displaystyle ~f(x)=\tan x~$ for $~x\in(-\pi /2,\pi / 2)~$ and of $~g(x)=\displaystyle \tan^{-1}x~$ are shown below. The dashed line $\displaystyle~y=x~$ is shown to help with your inquiry.

**TRUE** or **FALSE**

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/91520cf95b73561bbb8c5d0fcac08a13f10d64b6.png)

[[☃ dropdown 1]] $\displaystyle f\,^\prime(0)=g\,^\prime (0)$

[[☃ dropdown 2]] $\displaystyle f\,^\prime(x)\cdot g\,^\prime (x)>0~$ for $~x\in(-\pi /2,\pi / 2)\,$.

[[☃ dropdown 3]] $\displaystyle f\,^\prime(\pi /4)\cdot g\,^\prime (1)=1\,$.
